Fig. 1 Powder XRD patterns of (a) PdC2, (b) RuC2, (c) PdRuC2, (d) PdRuC2HT800 and (e) PdRuC2aged catalysts. Fig. 2 Normalized rates of p-CNB hydrogenation as a function of catalyst amount for the PdRuC2 catalyst after (a) 60min, (b) 75min and (c) 90min. Reaction condition: 1g p-CNB and 100mL EtOH at 35°C. Fig. 3 Time variation of p-CNB conversions over PdRuC2 catalyst in (a) powder form, (b) 85–100 mesh size and (c) 60–85 mesh size particles. Reaction condition: 1g p-CNB, 0.2g catalyst and 100mL EtOH at 35°C. Fig. 4 Hydrogenation of p-CNB as a function of time over PdRuC2 at different temperatures. Reaction condition: 1g p-CNB, 0.2g catalyst and 100mL EtOH at 35°C. Fig. 5 Effect of solvent on the hydrogenation of p-CNB over PdRuC2 at 35°C. Reaction condition: 1g p-CNB, 0.5g catalyst, 100mL solvent and for 75min reaction. Fig. 6 Time variation of p-CNB conversion over (a) as-prepared (AP), (b) HT500, (c) HT800 and (d) aged forms of PdRuC2 catalyst. Reaction condition: 1g p-CNB, 0.2g catalyst and 100mL EtOH at 35°C. Fig. 7 Transmission electron microscopic images of as-prepared samples of (a)–(d) PdC2, (e)–(g) RuC2 and (h)–(k) PdRuC2. Pd0.01Ru0.01Ce0.98O2−δ : A highly active and selective catalyst for the liquid phase hydrogenation of p-chloronitrobenzene under ambient conditions Rajib Mistri a 1 Jordi Llorca b Bidhan Chandra Ray a Arup Gayen a * a Department of Chemistry, Jadavpur University, Kolkata 700 032, India Department of Chemistry, Jadavpur University Kolkata 700 032 India b Institut de Tècniques Energètiques and Centre for Research in Nanoengineering, Universitat Politècnica de Catalunya, 08028 Barcelona, Spain Institut de Tècniques Energètiques and Centre for Research in Nanoengineering, Universitat Politècnica de Catalunya Barcelona 08028 Spain * Corresponding author. Tel.: +91 33 2457 2767; fax: +91 33 2414 6223. 1 Present address: Achhruram Memorial College, Jhalda 723 202, India. Graphical abstract Nanostructured bimetal ion substituted ceria, Pd0.01Ru0.01Ce0.98O2−δ (PdRuC2), prepared for the first time by a novel solution combustion synthesis and characterized employing XRD, BET, HRTEM and XPS has been shown to be very active and selective than the monometal ion substituted analogue Pd0.02Ce0.98O2−δ (PdC2), whereas Ru0.02Ce0.98O2−δ (RuC2) is inactive towards liquid phase hydrogenation of p-chloronitrobenzene to p-chloroaniline under ambient conditions. Structural studies show metal ion substituted ceria as the predominant phase. The hydrogenation over PdRuC2 is completed beyond 75min with 100% selectivity. Conversely, PdC2 hydrogenates ~40% of p-chloronitrobenzene with 82% selectivity. Increase of temperature from 35°C to 80°C showed a little higher activity of PdRuC2 but with a lower selectivity. The as-prepared and aged forms of PdRuC2 showed similar activity, whereas PdRuC2 heat-treated at 500°C increased the conversion and the 800°C heated catalyst reduced it (both ~2%) indicating high thermal stability. Maximum hydrogenation activity has been observed in ethanol as compared to methanol and butanol. The PdRuC2 catalyst also shows excellent hydrogenation activity towards o-, m-chloronitrobenzene and nitrobenzene. The enhancement of activity and selectivity of Pd in presence of Ru in the PdRu bimetal ionic catalyst for the hydrogenation reaction has been attributed to involvement of remarkable Ru4+-promotion in Pd0.01Ru0.01Ce0.98O2−δ . Keywords PdRu Ceria Ionic substitution Chloronitrobenzene hydrogenation Ru4+-promotion 1 Introduction Chloroanilines (CANs) are important intermediates in industry for synthesis of herbicides, pesticides, pigments, pharmaceuticals, cosmetics and commercially important organic fine chemicals [1,2]. The main synthesis routes to these chloroanilines involve selective hydrogenation of the corresponding nitro compounds over metal catalysts due to its lower impact on environment [3,4]. It is known that the catalytic hydrogenation of p-chloronitrobenzene (p-CNB) involves hydrodehalogenation to some extent, if right choices of catalysts are not used in the reaction medium [5]. Hence, designing a suitable catalyst system for the hydrogenation reaction is an important proposition. Several types of supported metal catalysts, like Pt [6–9], Ru–M (M=Sn, Pb and Ge) [10], Pt–M (M=Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni and Cu) [11–13], Ag [14], Ni [15,16], Au [17], Pd [1,3,18], Pd–Au [19], Ru [20], Rh [21], Pd–Ru [22,23], Pd–Pt [24] and Au–Pt [25] have been used with varying degree of success. Among these formulations, noble metal-based catalysts are primarily used in most of the chemical industries. Although supported Ru, Rh are selective, their catalytic activities are poor. Supported Pd catalysts, though show better activity, the selectivity is low. For base metal supported catalysts, use of foreign substances like NaOAC, pyridine, quinoline has also been reported to suppress the dechlorination reaction [26]. There has been ever growing interest in synthesizing uniform bimetallic nanoparticles as new catalysts for the organic reaction [24,27]. The suitable geometric and/or electronic effects of blending foreign metal atoms into metal structure allow the bimetallic metal nanoparticles with tunable catalytic properties. This has special importance in any new catalytic process where high activity and ultra high selectivity of product in environmental conscious manner are urgently required. In this work we show that Pd0.01Ru0.01Ce0.98O2−δ , prepared by a single step solution combustion method, has a much higher selective hydrogenation activity than the monometal ion substituted analogue Pd0.02Ce0.98O2−δ (whereas the Ru0.02Ce0.98O2−δ is inactive) towards p-CNB to p-CAN at room temperature and atmospheric pressure. The effect of changing various parameters on this reaction has also been investigated. A detailed analysis of the microstructure of the catalyst in its various forms supplemented with the XPS and XRD findings have enabled us to correlate the activity-selectivity patterns with the structure of the catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalyst We have synthesized the catalysts by single step solution combustion method in an open muffle furnace kept in a fume hood with exhaust by the combustion of the corresponding metal salts with oxalyldihydrazide [C2H6N4O2 (ODH)] as the fuel. Oxalyl dihydrazide was prepared by the dropwise addition of diethyl oxalate (C2H6N4O2, Sisco Research Laboratories Pvt. Ltd., 99%) to ice-cooled aqueous solution of hydrazine hydrate (N2H4·2H2O, Qualizens Fine Chemicals, 99%) as reported in [28]. The preparation of Pd0.01Ru0.01Ce0.98O2−δ involves combustion of the metal salts (NH4)2Ce(NO3)6, RuCl3·3H2O, PdCl2 with ODH, taken in a molar ratio 0.98:0.01:0.01:2.352, at the temperature of ignition of the redox mixture. In a typical preparation, 5g of (NH4)2Ce(NO3)6 (Loba Chemie, 99%), 1.64mL 1% PdCl2 (Spectrochem Pvt. Ltd., 99.9%) solution, 2.435mL 1% RuCl3·3H2O (Arora Matthey Pvt. Ltd., 40% Ru) solution and 2.5877g of ODH are dissolved in ~30mL of double distilled water in a borosilicate dish. The solution is then transferred to a preheated muffle furnace kept in a fume hood with exhaust and maintained at ~350°C. Initially the solution boils with frothing and foaming followed by complete dehydration when the surface gets ignited and burns with a flame yielding a voluminous solid product within a minute. We have also prepared Pd0.01Ce0.99O2−δ , Pd0.02Ce0.98O2−δ , Ru0.01Ce0.99O2−δ , Ru0.02Ce0.98O2−δ and Pd0.005Ru0.005Ce0.99O2−δ catalysts in a similar manner. The as prepared Pd0.01Ru0.01Ce0.98O2−δ has also been heated in air at 500°C and 800°C for 36h and named as heat-treated (HT) catalysts, HT500 and HT800, respectively. All the catalysts studied here are listed in Table 1 . PdRu with higher loading (3at.%, 1.5at.% each of Pd and Ru, catalyst PdRuC3 in Table 1) was also prepared in order to decide the best catalyst composition. 2.2 Characterization of catalysts The synthesized materials have been characterized by XRD, BET, HRTEM and XPS. X-ray powder diffraction patterns were collected in a Philips PW3040/60 X’pert PRO diffractometer (equipped with an X’celerator detector) operated at 40kV and 40mA, using Ni-filtered Cu-Kα radiation in the 2θ range 20–100° with a step size of 0.02° and a counting time of 80s per step. The BET surface areas were measured in a TriStar3000 surface area analyser (Micromeritics). Before each measurement, the samples were degassed at 150°C in vacuum for 60min. Microstructural characterization by high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) was performed at an accelerating voltage of 200kV in a JEOL 2010F instrument equipped with a field emission source. The point-to-point resolution was 0.19nm, and the resolution between lines was 0.14nm. The magnification was calibrated against a Si standard. No induced damage of the samples was observed under prolonged electron beam exposure. Samples were dispersed in alcohol in an ultrasonic bath, and a drop of supernatant suspension was poured onto a holey carbon-coated grid. Images were not filtered or treated by means of digital processing, and they correspond to raw data. Surface characterization was done with X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) on a SPECS system equipped with an Al anode XR50 source operating at 150mW and a Phoibos 150 MCD-9 detector. The pressure in the analysis chamber was always below 10−7 Pa. The area analysed was about 2mm×2mm. The pass energy of the hemispherical analyser was set at 25eV and the energy step was set at 0.1eV. Charge stabilization was achieved by using a SPECS Flood Gun FG 15/40. The sample powders were pressed to self-consistent disks. The following sequence of spectra was recorded: survey spectrum, C 1s, Ce 3d, Pd 3d, Ru 3p and C 1s again to check for charge stability as a function of time and the absence of degradation of the sample during the analyses. Data processing was performed with the CasaXPS programme (Casa Software Ltd., UK). The binding energy (BE) values were referred to the C 1s peak at 284.8eV. Atomic fractions (%) were calculated using peak areas normalized on the basis of acquisition parameters after background subtraction, experimental sensitivity factors and transmission factors provided by the manufacturer. 2.3 Catalytic test To test the catalytic activity we have fabricated a simple reaction setup in our laboratory. In this setup, the catalyst, reactant and liquid solvent are taken in a 250mL three-necked round bottom flask. The flask is fixed in an oil bath placed on a magnetic stirrer that helps to achieve homogeneity of the reaction mixture. A heating coil, connected to a temperature controller and powered with a variac can be used for heating purpose when required. The gas lines are made up of silicone rubber. The reacting (purging) gasses [H2 (N2)] were fed to the system using proper gas regulators via a “T” connector which flows through a bubbler of paraffin oil before entry to the reactor. This “T” connector allows flow of the reacting gas or purging/carrier gas or both. The gas outlet also passes through a similar bubbler. An upper end sealed bulb water condenser is connected to the flask for condensation of reaction mixture. Pure N2 was used to purge the reactor before performing any catalytic test. All the gases were obtained from Indian Refrigeration Stores, Kolkata and were of UHP quality (>99.9%). In a typical catalytic run, the catalyst in its powder form and 100mL EtOH (Changshu Yangyuan Chemical, China, 99.9%) are taken in a 250mL three-necked round bottom flask and purged with N2 (about 125mL/min for 2min) more than five times (total ~10min) under constant stirring (rpm=900) to get an inert reaction atmosphere. Then the gas flow was switched over to pure hydrogen flow (30mL/min). After 30min of hydrogen flow, 1g p-CNB (BDH Chemicals Pvt. Ltd., England, 99.3%) dissolved in minimum volume of ethanol (~5mL) was injected into the reaction medium. The reaction compositions were analysed by taking small amounts of liquid reaction mixture at different time intervals and analysed using Waters Alliance 2695 Separations Module equipped with built-in auto samplers (Waters, Milford, MA, USA) liquid chromatography equipped with Quattro micro API triple-quadrupole mass spectrometer (Micromass, Manchester, UK) fitted with a Z-spray electrospray interface in positive ion mode detector. A 5.0μm reverse phase C18 Polaris column (50mm×4.6mm) [Varian Inc., Lake Forest, CA, USA] is used for the separation of products and was determined by quantitative calculation of the area percentage. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 XRD studies Powder XRD patterns of different catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 . All the diffraction lines can be indexed to the fluorite structure of Ceria (Fm3m) and diffraction lines due to Pd or Ru metal or their oxides could not be detected even with a very slow scan (not shown) performed in the range 2θ =25–50°. So, under highly oxidizing preparation condition, metal oxides are not observed. We can speculate that the metal ion is probably substituted for Ce4+ in CeO2 matrix in line with our previous reports in these kinds of systems [29]. 3.2 BET studies The surface areas of the catalysts are low, fall in the range 12–15m2 g−1 (see Table 1) and follows the order RuC2<PdRuC2<PdC2. There occurs sintering of PdRuC2 catalyst on thermal treatment at 800°C, the surface area decreases by about 38% (from 13.6m2 g−1 in as-prepared form to ~8m2 g−1 in HT800 form). Thermal treatment at 500°C and ageing in the reaction atmosphere (for 6h) has no appreciable effect on the surface area of PdRuC2 catalyst. For these rather low surface area materials, the activity patterns of PdRuC2 in its as-prepared, heat-treated and aged forms are similar as will be shown latter indicating no appreciable role of surface area in deciding the activity of the different forms of this catalyst. This point to the structure of PdRuC2 as the responsible factor to decide the activity behaviour. 3.3 Activity studies 3.3.1 Screening of catalysts Hydrogenation activities of p-CNB to p-CAN in Pd, Ru and PdRu catalysts at room temperature and atmospheric pressure are incorporated in Table 2 . The PdRuC2 catalyst shows much higher reactivity and selectivity than the other catalysts. Using ethanol as solvent, p-chlorophenylhydroxylamine (p-ClPhNHOH) was produced as the byproduct (just about 1%) in this process. With PdRuC2 as catalyst, both reactivity and selectivity to p-CAN are 100% after 75min of reaction. However the reactivity is less than 40% in other catalysts and selectivity is also below 82% after 120min barring RuC1 and RuC2 that are inactive. It is to be noted that even the PdRuC1 catalyst (having overall 1at.% metal component, 0.5at.% each of Pd and Ru) although show a lower conversion than PdC2 after 120min of hydrogenation, it shows higher activity as well as selectivity (70% and 98%, respectively) when the reaction time was increased from 120min to 180min. Maximum activity is achieved at a metal loading of overall 2at.% on ceria (1at.% each of Pd and Ru). So we choose PdRuC2 as the catalyst for further investigations. Higher loading of PdRu (overall 3at.%, 1.5at.% each of Pd and Ru) in ceria gave a high conversion (99%) but a lower selectivity (88%) because of aniline formation (11%) and hence will not be discussed further. 3.3.2 Effect of mass transfer influences on the hydrogenation After screening of the mono and bimetal ionic catalysts, a number of preliminary tests were performed over the PdRuC2 catalyst to investigate possible influences caused by mass transfer phenomena. We used the catalyst in its power (finely divided) forms and used a sufficiently high rpm to reduce/eliminate any mass transfer influence in the reaction. It is to be noted that any change in the quantity of catalyst used will affect the observed rate of reaction even when the chemical reaction is limiting. That is why we employed a very simple procedure to understand whether the hydrogenation is being run under mass transfer limitations. The procedure involves determining the normalized rate (rate per unit mass of the catalyst) which should not change much (lies within ±5%) when the catalyst amount is halved [30]. Fig. 2 incorporates the normalized rates at three different time intervals. For a reaction time of 60min, the deviation of normalized rate using 500mg catalyst (~46%) is far greater than the allowed deviation (±5%). But the deviation of this rate reduces appreciably when the reaction time is increased to 75min (~15% deviation) and it falls within the limit after 90min of hydrogenation. Hence the mass transfer effect decreases appreciably with the increase of reaction time beyond 75min and it did not significantly influence the global reaction rate after 90min of reaction time. Thus, we conclude that the conversions and TOFs reported in Table 2 corresponding to reaction time ≥75min using 500mg of catalyst is only slightly affected by mass transfer. Now, the possible effect of intraparticle diffusion could not be completely ruled out and so we also studied the influence of catalyst particle size on the reaction rate. For this purpose, we carried out the hydrogenation reaction using as synthesized powder catalyst and also different mesh sized catalysts keeping all other reaction parameters constant. The findings are shown in Fig. 3 . It can be seen that with larger catalyst particle (smaller mesh size) the hydrogenation activity is lower and the as-synthesized powder catalyst shows a higher conversion compared to the larger catalyst particles. This indicates the presence of some liquid/solid mass transfer limitation on the reaction with larger sized catalyst particles [30]. The as-synthesized catalysts are fine powders with which these diffusion limitations are minimal or negligible and these have been used throughout our study. 3.3.3 Effect of temperature and reaction time Reaction conditions have been reported to have some influences on the hydrogenation rate and the selectivity in the hydrogenation of halonitrobenzenes over supported metal catalysts [31,32]. We also carried out hydrogenation at temperatures higher than RT (limited to 80°C since this is the b.p. of the solvent ethanol used in this study) using a lower amount (200mg) of catalyst keeping all the other reaction parameters constant at different time intervals and this is incorporated in Fig. 4 . Note that the conversion increases more or less linearly with time up to 105min with 100% selectivity. The four temperatures studied here can be categorized into two ranges. Between 35 and 40°C, the activity is similar and then the conversion increases by 3–5% and remains similar in the temperature range 60–80°C. After 75min, the p-CNB conversion was about 35% in the first temperature range and then it increased to about 40% in the second temperature range. Thus, we note that the PdRuC2 catalyst shows a little higher activity at the highest temperature of 80°C as compared to the activity at RT. Since the catalyst is already very active at RT, the increase of temperature does not affect the activity significantly in the studied temperature range. But it is to be noted that the selectivity is lower at this high temperature because of formation of about 2% aniline after 120min of reaction. These results are understandable since higher temperatures usually lead to faster reactions, but they may also activate other bonds such as CCl bond to form aniline. 3.3.4 Effect of solvent Fig. 5 shows the hydrogenation activity of PdRuC2 in three solvents. The activity and selectivity is maximum in ethanol (complete conversion with 100% selectivity after 75min of reaction). The conversion decreases to ~72% in methanol and further below to 48% in butanol with more than 85% selectivity. The solvent plays an important role in controlling the substrate catalyst interaction. It is preliminarily adsorbed on the catalysts surface. More polar solvent is firmly adsorbed on the catalyst surface and hence disfavours the p-CNB adsorption decreasing the hydrogenation activity. In addition to this, the steric effect of absorbed solvent can also decrease the substrate adsorptions and this in turn decreases the hydrogenation activity. There is usually a competition between the solvent polarity and steric effect. Now, the solvent polarity increases in the order methanol>ethanol>butanol and the steric effect increases in the reverse order. In case of ethanol both are moderate, so it shows the highest activity. Also, the main reaction product p-CAN and the byproduct p-ClPhNHOH through which the reaction proceeds are more soluble in polar solvents. For a highly polar solvent like MeOH, the selectivity decreases due to more solubility of p-ClPhNHOH which can leave the catalyst surface more easily before conversion to p-CAN. On the other hand, in a solvent of comparatively lower polarity, the product desorption will be lower and so the selectivity will be higher. In butanol, although less polar than ethanol, the selectivity decreases due to more pronounced steric effect of the absorbed solvent on p-ClPhNHOH which now leaves the catalyst surface more easily before conversion to p-CAN. Hence, a moderately polar and bulky solvent like ethanol shows higher activity and selectivity for this hydrogenation reaction. 3.3.5 Effect of reagent amount Table 3 lists the hydrogenation activities of PdRuC2 catalyst using a varied amount of p-CNB after different time intervals under the same reaction conditions. Complete conversion is achieved for a reagent amount of 1g with 100% selectivity after 75min of reaction. Doubling the reagent amount to 2g decreased the conversion to about 73% and is associated with a decrease of selectivity (~94%) because of the formation of byproduct after 120min of reaction. Continuation of hydrogenation for further one hour results in an increase of both the activity and selectivity. When the p-CNB amount was increased by five times, the conversion was between 50 and 60%. No further increase of byproduct formation was noted again suggesting very good selectivity (>92%) of the catalyst. Thus, under the chosen reaction conditions, hydrogenation for 75min can completely convert a maximum of 1g of p-CNB to p-CAN. Further increase of p-CNB amount results in a lower catalyst/reagent ratio and thus a decreased conversion as well as selectivity even after longer duration of reaction. This is understandable since not all the reactant molecules can get adsorbed on the catalyst surface for reaction and the intermediate p-ClPhNHOH also can escape the surface before conversion to p-CAN decreasing the selectivity. When a major portion of p-CNB is converted after 120min, further increase of reaction time to 180min allows some more reactant conversion because of more availability of catalyst surface increasing the overall conversion. This also enhances the possibility of conversion of the intermediate to the product p-CAN before going into the solution leading to increased selectivity. 3.3.6 Effect of thermal treatment and ageing We have also investigated the effect of thermal treatment (at 500°C and 800°C for 36h) on the stability of PdRuC2 and subsequently investigated their activity. Fig. 6 compares the hydrogenation activity of as-prepared, heat-treated and aged PdRuC2 catalysts at different time intervals. The activity pattern follows the order: HT500>AP≈aged>HT800. Interestingly, the as-prepared and aged (in the reaction atmosphere for 6h) catalysts showed almost the same activity at all time intervals. The by-product is formed only to a little extent up to a reaction time of 75min, beyond which p-CAN is the only hydrogenation product. Thermal treatment at 500°C has a little positive effect (conversion increases by about 2%) on the activity pattern of as-prepared catalyst. But heating of the catalyst at 800°C for 36h reduces the activity by just about 2–3%. Thus the PdRuC2 catalyst is essentially stable up to 800°C. It is to be kept in mind that this slight loss of activity at the high temperature of 800°C is not of concern for our present study because the as-prepared catalyst is already very active at room temperature and the catalyst heat-treated at 500°C is slightly more active. The nearly similar activities of heat-treated catalysts indicate that no appreciable loss of Ru due to evaporation happen even at 800°C. This is very important because Ru-based catalysts have this inherent problem and it is interesting to efficiently incorporate Ru in the catalyst in order to maintain the activity. From the foregoing results it becomes obvious that the hydrogenation activity in the combustion synthesized catalysts is only due to palladium. Thus, ruthenium in the bimetal ion substituted catalyst (PdRuC2) acts as a remarkable promoter to increase the activity of palladium with 100% selectivity. It is also to be noted that the activity remains unaltered for consecutive cycles. The essentially unaltered hydrogenation activity of as-prepared, heat-treated, recycled and aged PdRuC2 catalyst must then be attributed to the unchanged structure of the catalyst. 3.3.7 Hydrogenation of o- and m-CNB and nitrobenzene It is of great interest to see if the PdRuC2 catalyst can be a general catalytic system for the hydrogenation of other chloronitrobenzenes and the parent compound nitrobenzene. Hydrogenation activity of o-CNB, p-CNB and nitrobenzene (NB) was thus tested over this catalyst and the results are summarized in Table 4 . As expected the o- and m-derivatives show similar activity (o- and m-CNB gives ~98% and ~96% of the corresponding aniline after 75min of reaction) with more than 99% selectivity and for the parent compound NB, a relatively lower activity is observed. Nevertheless, the NB to aniline (AN) conversion was 86% after 75min that increased to 93% after 120min and hydrogenation was complete beyond 180min of reaction with 100% selectivity. Thus, PdRuC2 has the potential to be used as a general hydrogenation catalyst for these types of organic molecules. Table 2 also lists the TOF values for various catalysts calculated considering the total moles of metal component taken in the preparation. As because Ru has been found to be inactive towards the reaction and it is the Pd component that contributes to the activity, we have calculated the TOF values of the bimetal ionic catalysts in reference to Pd-only and those are also incorporated in table. The TOF over PdRuC2 is almost four times that over PdC2 considering total metal (Pd and Ru both) and it is more than eight times if we consider Pd-only value. Although the TOF reported by Liu et al. for this hydrogenation on PVP-Ru/Pd colloids is higher than our calculated TOFs, the selectivity obtained by them is much less [22]. The TOF's are similar for all the three chloronitrobenzenes, namely 4.83×10−2, 4.73×10−2 and 4.64×10−2 s−1, respectively for the p-, o- and m-CNB after 75min of hydrogenation (see Table 4). For the hydrogenation of NB, a TOF of 5.34×10−2 s−1 was obtained. 3.4 Microstructural studies A low magnification view of PdC2 (see Fig. 7(a)) shows it to be comprised by small (5–8nm) and large (~50nm) ceria crystallites. Numerous, randomly oriented ceria crystallites are visible and their electron diffraction pattern (inset in Fig. 7(b)) shows the expected CeO2 rings with spacing at 3.12, 2.71, 1.91, 1.63 and 1.56Å ascribed to (111), (200), (220), (311) and (222) crystallographic planes, respectively. A lattice-fringe image of PdC2 sample (Fig. 7(c)) shows tiny palladium particles with a mean particle size of about 1nm. In addition, the support shows evidence of structural distortion. FT image of the support (Fig. 7(d)) shows multiple spots clustered around the crystallographic nominal values, which points to the formation of Pd–O–Ce phase [29]. Moreover, additional spots at 5.7Å are indicative of Pd–O–Ce superstructure formation (as discussed in [29]). In Fig. 7(d), lattice fringes of Pd (111) at 2.2Å are recognized in various particles, which likely have an epitaxial relationship with the support particle. Sample RuC2 also contains both large and small CeO2 crystallites, as shown in Fig. 7(e). Ruthenium particles in the range of 2–4nm are well dispersed over the support (Fig. 7(f)). Spots at 3.12Å due to CeO2 (111) planes are aligned with spots at 2.14Å of Ru (002) crystallographic planes, suggesting epitaxial growth. It merits to be highlighted that in this sample there is no Ru–O–Ce superstructure formation, since neither extra spots appear in the FT images nor strips or clustered spots. Thus, it appears that M–O–Ce superstructure formation is restricted to Pd only. In Fig. 7(g) several Ru particles of 2–4nm in size are shown. Spots at 2.34Å are due to Ru (100) planes. A general view of as-prepared PdRuC2 is depicted in Fig. 7(h). A lattice fringe view is shown in Fig. 7(i), where several particles of 2–4nm are identified. Given their dimension, these particles are likely ruthenium. Fig. 7(j) corresponds to another part of the sample in which small particles of about 1nm are well distributed over the support. Given their similarity to the particles present in sample PdC2, these particles in sample PdRuC2 are likely palladium. Interestingly, the FT image of the ceria support exhibit several spots clustered around the nominal pure CeO2 values, thus suggesting the existence again of a Pd–O–Ce structure. A comprehensive image is provided in Fig. 7(k). In this image, individual Ru and Pd particles as well as Pd–O–Ce superstructure are identified. The FT image corresponds to the Pd–O–Ce support, whereas an individual Ru particle showing (002) fringes at 2.14Å is indicated along with an individual Pd cluster, too small for exhibiting lattice fringes. Thus, in PdC2, Pd is encountered both in individual Pd entities of about 1nm in diameter and in a surface Pd–O–Ce superstructure. In RuC2, Ru is encountered only in individual Ru crystallites of about 2–4nm in diameter. In PdRuC2, the Pd–O–Ce superstructure is maintained along with individual Pd and Ru particles of ca. 1 and 2–4nm, respectively. Note that ordering of the superstructure originates extra spots in HRTEM because the symmetry order decreases, but the absence of such extra spots does not eliminate metal ion incorporation in the CeO2 lattice. If incorporation is random there will be no extra spots. So, random Ru–O–Ce phase is likely there for Ru, whereas supercell structure is present in Pd–O–Ce. No evidence for alloy formation between Pd and Ru is encountered, although the possibility of surface alloy cannot be completely ruled out by HRTEM measurements over these rather small metallic particles. The heated sample PdRuC2HT500 is similar to the sample PdRuC2 (see Fig. 8(a)–(c)). The only difference is that Ru particles maintain their size after heating (2–4nm), but Pd particles experience a size growth, from about 1nm in sample PdRuC2 up to 2–3nm in sample PdRuC2HT500. This is clear from particle size distribution measurements over Fig. 8(a)–(c) corresponding to sample PdRuC2HT500. Upon sintering, Pd particles develop crystallographic facets, as shown in Fig. 8(c) for an individual Pd crystallite oriented along the [110] crystallographic direction. In Fig. 8(b), the FT image corresponding to the support particle indicates that the existence of the Pd–O–Ce superstructure is maintained after heating. The sample aged in the reaction atmosphere for 6h, PdRuC2aged, is indistinguishable from the fresh sample PdRuC2 (Fig. 8(d)–(f)). In Fig. 8(d) several Ru particles of 2–4nm in diameter are well dispersed over the support particles. Pd entities are also present in a highly dispersed form of about 1nm, as shown in Fig. 8(e). A FT image is enclosed corresponding to the support particle, where spots at 2.9–3.2Å are likely to originate from the existence of the Pd–O–Ce phase. In Fig. 8(f) several Ru particles are depicted and identified on the basis of their lattice fringes. 3.5 XPS studies XPS of Pd(3d) and Ru(3p) regions of fresh PdRuC2 are shown in Fig. 9 . The Pd(3d5/2,3/2) peaks at 338 and 343.2eV can be attributed to Pd in 2+ oxidation state [33]. Similarly, Ru(3p3/2,1/2) peaks at 363.3 and 486.4eV are due to Ru4+ ions in ceria [34]. In each spectra, the lower energy shoulder (negligibly smaller for Pd) indicates signature of metallic components in line with the HRTEM findings. The Ce(3d) spectra (not included) with characteristic satellite features correspond to cerium in 4+ oxidation state. For the fresh sample, the atomic composition of the surface is: 30.7% Ce, 65.6% O, 1.8% Pd and 1.9% Ru. The ratio Ce/O corresponds to that expected for CeO2, and the high values of Pd/Ce and Ru/Ce (about 0.06 for both) indicate a good dispersion of the metal component. In particular, there is about 6 times enhancement in surface concentration of Pd and Ru in the PdRuC2 catalyst than that of bulk concentration, clearly indicating surface segregation of Pd and Ru mostly as ions on CeO2 crystallites surface. XPS study thus confirms ionic dispersion of Pd and Ru on the surface of CeO2 crystallites. Also, the atomic ratio Pd/Ru is close to one as taken in the preparation of the catalyst, indicating that no preferred segregation of any of the two metals occurs. It is not easy to quantify metallic particles against oxidized ones because air exposure might oxidize their surface (1–2 atomic layers), which would be detected by XPS but not by HRTEM. The catalytic studies have shown that the HT500 catalyst is little more active than the as-prepared and aged catalysts, whereas the activity of HT800 catalyst is a bit lower. Our thorough microstructural study shows no major differences in the microstructure except that Pd particles are very small in size (about 1nm) in the as-prepared and aged PdRuC2 catalysts whereas the Pd particle size increases to 2–3nm in the HT500 catalyst. There is neither any difference in the surface area of these three forms of PdRuC2 catalyst. It seems therefore that the smaller Pd crystallites do not participate in the hydrogenation whereas when they grow on heating to about 2–3nm as in the HT500 catalyst, there is some active participation of these crystallites in the hydrogenation reaction as is evident from the slightly higher activity of the HT500 catalyst as compared to the as-prepared and aged catalysts. This has some resemblance with the findings by Krillov and Ryndin who found that a higher dispersion of smaller Pd particles having a lower electron density shows lower hydrogenation activity [35]. Good hydrogenation properties have also been obtained on large Pt particles for Pt/Al2O3 catalysts by Coq et al. [6] and for bimetallic PtSn/nylon catalysts by Galvagno et al. [36] and poorly dispersed Ru-catalysts by Tijani et al. [10]. The predominant role towards hydrogenation is still played by the ionic palladium species which is the major Pd-species present in the combustion synthesized catalysts. We are not very concerned with the HT800 catalyst because such high temperature stability is not a prerequisite for the present study. We just wanted to look into the stability of the catalyst and its influence on the hydrogenation activity pattern. The finding is promising since there is just a mere loss of activity of the HT800 catalyst compared to the as-prepared one. We attribute this loss to originate from (a) loss of surface area and (b) there may be some loss of the ruthenium component on prolonged heating at 800°C. There are a number of studies wherein chloronitrobenzene hydrogenation activities have been shown to be promoted in presence of a second metal component. Han et al. has shown that the CNB hydrogenation over Pt/ZrO2 is improved with the introduction of rare earths with the maximum using praseodymium and they attributed this to an electronic effect by the rare earths which activate the nitrogen–oxygen bond [37]. They also found such a promotional effect when a transition metal is incorporated in Pt/TiO2 catalyst, the highest effect was observed in presence of iron [11]. Coq et al. showed that suboxide TiO x species promotes the properties of Pt particles in Pt/Al2O3 catalyst [9]. A SMSI effect between Ni-particles and TiO x species produced on reduction has been explained to be responsible for the best performance over the Ni/TiO2 catalyst by Xiong et al. [38]. Xu et al. have shown that Sn4+ played an excellent promoting role over PVP-Pd/γ-Al2O3 for both the hydrogenation activity of p-CNB and the selectivity of forming p-CAN [39]. Vishwanathan et al. have reported the effect of alkali metal promotion in alumina-supported palladium catalysts where both the stability during on-stream activity tests and resistance to coke formation is improved over the promoted catalyst with respect to the unpromoted one [40]. Liu et al. investigated the metal ions Fe3+, Ni2+ and Co2+ supported on Pt colloids, which displayed different modification roles for the hydrogenation reactions [41]. Whereas Co2+ increased both the activity and selectivity, Fe3+ decreased the activity of Pt/PS (PS=poly styrene-co-divinylbenzene) catalyst and Ni2+ increased the selectivity but decreased the activity. Liu et al. have reported a significant role of Fe3+ towards PVP-Ru/Pd and that of Co2+ towards PVP-Ru/Pt [22]. Thus, a positive role towards CNB hydrogenation is played by either an alkali metal ion or a transition metal ion or rare earths. Our study brings about the promoting role played by a noble metal ion Ru4+ present as substitutional ion in the ceria lattice. Interestingly, whereas PdC2 (Pd2+ in ceria) shows activity towards hydrogenation, RuC2 (Ru4+ in ceria) is inactive under our reaction conditions. But the presence of Ru together with Pd enhanced the activity as well as selectivity as observed over PdRuC2. Our study shows ionic dispersion of Pd2+ and Ru4+ on the reducible support ceria leading to the formation of ionic Pd–O–Ce and Ru–O–Ce moieties. Ceria can also provide oxide-ion vacancies that can coordinate to the oxygen atom of NO and contributes to its polarization, as reported for TiO x support [9,38]. Ionic Pd–O–Ce moiety makes easy supply of hydride ion by dissociative adsorption of the hydrogen molecule. On the other hand, ionic Ru–O–Ce moiety acts as a promoter to attract the lone pair of oxygen atom of NO bond, thereby increasing its polarity and making easier hydrogen abstraction, which causes an enhancement of the activity. The highly polarized NO bond also delocalizes the lone pair electrons of p-orbitals of the Cl atom towards the phenyl ring, making CCl bond unfavourable for hydrogenation, which results in an increase of the selectivity [11,13,39,40]. The very high activity and selectivity of PdRu bimetal ion substituted ceria at RT thus suggests the involvement of this remarkable Ru4+-promotion in the catalyst. In case of chloronitrobenzene, the electronic effect of Cl in presence of metal ions activates the NO bond in the order of p>o>m, so the hydrogenation rate of CNB follows the same order [6,36]. 4 Conclusions In this study, activity of bimetal ion substituted ceria (PdRuC2) catalyst is compared with the corresponding monometal ion substituted catalysts (PdC2 and RuC2) and the important conclusions are: (i) A single step solution combustion method leads to a novel Pd0.01Ru0.01Ce0.98O2−δ catalyst that shows higher activity and selectivity for p-chloronitrobenzene hydrogenation compared to monometal ion substituted analogue Pd0.02Ce0.98O2−δ under ambient conditions. The Ru0.02Ce0.98O2−δ is found to be inactive. (ii) The structural studies show metal ion substituted in ceria as the predominant phase that is associated with finely dispersed nano metal crystallites. (iii) Presence of Ru4+ together with Pd2+ on ceria plays crucial role towards hydrogenation of p-CNB without dechlorination indicating remarkable Ru4+-promotion in the bimetal ion substituted ceria catalyst. (iv) The PdRuC2 catalyst has also been shown to be an effective catalytic formulation for the hydrogenation of other chloronitrobenzenes, namely o- and m-chloronitrobenzene and nitrobenzene. It is expected that this catalyst has the potential to act as a general catalyst for several other nitrobenzene derivatives of concomitant interest. coredata.dc:description: Nanostructured bimetal ion substituted ceria, Pd0.01Ru0.01Ce0.98O2−δ (PdRuC2), prepared for the first time by a novel solution combustion synthesis and characterized employing XRD, BET, HRTEM and XPS has been shown to be very active and selective than the monometal ion substituted analogue Pd0.02Ce0.98O2−δ (PdC2), whereas Ru0.02Ce0.98O2−δ (RuC2) is inactive towards liquid phase hydrogenation of p-chloronitrobenzene to p-chloroaniline under ambient conditions. Structural studies show metal ion substituted ceria as the predominant phase. The hydrogenation over PdRuC2 is completed beyond 75min with 100% selectivity. Conversely, PdC2 hydrogenates ~40% of p-chloronitrobenzene with 82% selectivity. Increase of temperature from 35°C to 80°C showed a little higher activity of PdRuC2 but with a lower selectivity. The as-prepared and aged forms of PdRuC2 showed similar activity, whereas PdRuC2 heat-treated at 500°C increased the conversion and the 800°C heated catalyst reduced it (both ~2%) indicating high thermal stability. Maximum hydrogenation activity has been observed in ethanol as compared to methanol and butanol. The PdRuC2 catalyst also shows excellent hydrogenation activity towards o-, m-chloronitrobenzene and nitrobenzene. The enhancement of activity and selectivity of Pd in presence of Ru in the PdRu bimetal ionic catalyst for the hydrogenation reaction has been attributed to involvement of remarkable Ru4+-promotion in Pd0.01Ru0.01Ce0.98O2−δ .
coredata.dc:title: Pd0.01Ru0.01Ce0.98O2−δ : A highly active and selective catalyst for the liquid phase hydrogenation of p-chloronitrobenzene under ambient conditions
